fields.value: Survey of Federal Government Employees, November 1991-February 1992 [United States]

authorName.value: United States Office of Personnel Management

authorAffiliation.value: United States Office of Personnel Management

dsDescriptionValue.value:
The Survey of Federal Employees is the Office of Personnel   Management's first major survey of the work force since 1983. The   questionnaire was designed to provide policy-makers with information   that was not available from existing sources. Questions covered various   personnel areas such as employee characteristics, employees'   satisfaction with their jobs, supervisors, and organizations,   performance management, training, work schedule arrangements, leave   benefits, and dependent care responsibil
ities and the ways employees  fulfill these responsibilities.

topicClassValue.value: ICPSR VIII.A. Governmental Structures, Policies, and Capabilities, Behavior and Attitudes of Bureaucrats

fields.value: Version Date: 1993-05-13Version Text: 1993-05-13 Subject: null  Type: null  Notes: Card Image with SPSS Control Cards;Subject: Study Level Error Note, Notes: This data collection contains four samples: a main   sample and three subsamples. No documentation is provided for these   subsamples. The SPSS Control Cards and questionnaire document the main   sample, which includes 31,645 of the total 42,194 cases. The SPSS   Control Cards contain a statement designed to subset the main sample  from the total.; Subject: null  Type: null  Notes: Data file(s), and electronic documentation.;

distributorName.value: Inter-university Consortium for Political and Social Research

distributorAffiliation.value: Institute for Social Research, University of Michigan

value: All federal white-collar employees in the group of federal  agencies participating in the survey.

fields.value: A primary random sample of 56,767 federal employees was   stratified by department and by pay category. Since samples were not   proportional to department or to pay category population size, survey   responses were weighted to represent accurate group proportions within  the overall federal white-collar population.
